results_summary: The study found that aerobic walking improved aerobic fitness, motor function, fatigue, mood, executive control, and quality of life in mild to moderate PD, with no serious adverse events reported. Preliminary analyses suggested higher musculoskeletal adverse events in the interval training group, leading to a shift to continuous training.
population_specificity: Independently ambulatory patients with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: 3 times per week, 45 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of decompression surgery versus nonoperative treatment on reducing the risk of falling in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The surgery group showed significant improvements in functional mobility tests (e.g., Six-Meter Walk test, timed "Up & Go" test) and a reduced risk of falling compared to the nonoperative group, though both groups saw improvements in disability and quality-of-life scores.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (mean age 62.4 in surgery group, 64.6 in nonoperative group).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 3 months and 1 year post-intervention.

study_goal: To determine if Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) via a foot drop stimulator (FDS) could retrain tibialis anterior (TA) activation timing during walking in stroke survivors.
results_summary: After 4 weeks of FDS use, TA activation during walking without the device more closely matched the pre-programmed FDS timing, indicating neuromuscular retraining. The burst duration similarity index (BDSI) improved in all participants (P = 0.05).
population_specificity: Individuals with stroke (n = 4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the feasibility of improving foot drop and arm swing in hemiplegic patients using a functional electrical stimulator during walking.
results_summary: After four weeks of training, post-stroke patients showed statistically significant improvements in arm swing angle (7.16%, 43.06%, and 54.66% across three patients). The method demonstrated potential to enhance gait and arm swing in hemiplegic patients.
population_specificity: Post-stroke hemiplegic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether unstable shoes could reduce low back pain in health professionals with chronic nonspecific low back pain.
results_summary: The intervention group wearing unstable shoes showed a significant decrease in pain scores and higher satisfaction rates compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in disability or quality of life scores.
population_specificity: Health professionals with nonspecific chronic low back pain (n=40).
effective_dosage: Wearing unstable shoes (MBT Fora) for at least 6 hours per workday.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) could alleviate symptoms of diabetic sensorimotor polyneuropathy (DSPNP), particularly pain and walking abilities.
results_summary: ESWT reduced pain intensity from 100% to 23.6% after 2 weeks, though it rose to 45.7% by 8 weeks. Walking abilities improved significantly by the 8th week, with step length increasing by 14.6%, walking speed by 24.8%, and dual support time decreasing by 12.2%.
population_specificity: 14 patients with DSPNP (excluding 10 diabetic patients for inhomogeneous performance).
effective_dosage: 3 times weekly for 2 weeks using the Duolith® shock wave generator.
study_duration: 2 weeks of active treatment, with follow-ups at 2, 4, and 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether decompression surgery for lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) indirectly improved blood glucose control (measured by HbA1c levels) by enabling increased physical activity.
results_summary: The study found that surgical treatment significantly reduced HbA1c levels in LSS patients with DM, likely due to increased physical activity post-surgery, while conservative treatment did not show similar improvements. Pain and disability scores improved in both groups, but only the surgical group showed significant reductions in total cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Patients with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis and Type 2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical or conservative treatment, not a walking dosage).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments occurred at two unspecified time points post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two different injection techniques (2 sites vs. 4 sites) of botulinum toxin in improving walking ability in stroke patients with spastic equinovarus deformity.
results_summary: Both injection techniques significantly improved walking time over 10 meters, but there was no significant difference in effectiveness between the two methods. Fewer injection sites were suggested to minimize discomfort and potential antibody production while achieving similar therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with spastic equinovarus deformity seen at King Hussein Medical Center, Amman, Jordan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (botulinum toxin injected at 2 sites in group I and 4 sites in group II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an 8-week yoga intervention versus walking on diabetes risk factors and psychological well-being in high-risk individuals.
results_summary: Walking showed significant reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, total cholesterol, anxiety, depression, negative affect, and perceived stress, but no significant differences in fasting blood glucose, postprandial blood glucose, or insulin resistance compared to yoga.
population_specificity: Indians with elevated fasting blood glucose in Bangalore, India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether stationary stepping could serve as a surrogate task for treadmill walking by comparing stride behavior characteristics.
results_summary: At the group level, stride behavior was similar between stationary stepping and treadmill walking, but individual-level analyses showed poor reliability in most metrics, suggesting stationary stepping may not be a suitable surrogate for treadmill walking.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (N = 10)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (tasks: 15-minute treadmill walking and stationary stepping)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of cardiac contractility modulation (CCM) on functional capacity and quality of life in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that CCM significantly improved peak oxygen consumption, 6-minute walk test distance, and quality of life, though the effects were modest.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in lung volume and density following endobronchial coiling for lung volume reduction and correlate these with clinical improvements in walking distance (6-m walk test) and pulmonary function.
results_summary: Responders showed a significant increase in walking distance (70 ± 11 m) and FEV1 values (61 ± 21 mL), with volume reduction in the treated lobe and expansion in the untreated ipsilateral lobe. These changes were linked to clinical improvement in responders.
population_specificity: 17 patients (8 men, 9 women) with pulmonary conditions treated by endobronchial coiling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of intrathecal baclofen therapy for improving spasticity and gait in patients with hereditary spastic paraplegia.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in lower limb spasticity and improved walking ability in patients treated with intrathecal baclofen. Two patients required re-operation due to catheter fractures.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients diagnosed with hereditary spastic paraplegia (mean age: 43 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a cognitive behavioral therapy program combined with exercise (including walking) on individuals with refractory chronic pain.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain intensity, disability, catastrophizing thoughts, and physical function measures (e.g., seated forward bends, zig-zag walking, self-care, and 6-minute walk test) after the intervention.
population_specificity: 46 patients with refractory chronic pain in Japan.
effective_dosage: Weekly sessions of approximately 2 hours, combining lectures with exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tablet-based and brochure-based home-based strength-balance training programs on gait quality and physical performance in elderly individuals.
results_summary: Tablet-guided training significantly improved single and dual task walking compared to brochure-guided training, with active participants outperforming inactive ones in gait and physical performance measures. Social and individual motivation strategies were equally effective.
population_specificity: Autonomous-living elderly people (mean age 75, SD 6 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week progressive home-based strength-balance training program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of water-based exercise with and without cognitive stimuli on cognitive and physical functions, including walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that normal water-based exercise (Nor-WE) significantly improved walking ability and lower limb muscle strength, while cognitive water-based exercise (Cog-WE) enhanced cognitive functions like attention, memory, and learning.
population_specificity: Elderly adults
effective_dosage: 10 min of walking, 30 min of strength/stepping exercise (Nor-WE) or water-cognitive exercises (Cog-WE), and 10 min of stretching/relaxation in water, per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and radiographic outcomes between direct anterior (DA-THA) and mini-posterior approach (MPA-THA) total hip arthroplasty, focusing on recovery metrics like time to ambulation without assistive devices.
results_summary: Patients undergoing DA-THA stopped using walking aids 6 days earlier than those with MPA-THA (22 vs. 28 days, P=0.04). No significant additional clinical or radiographic benefits were observed between the two approaches.
population_specificity: 54 patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty.
study_duration: Follow-up until ambulation without assistive devices (average 22-28 days).

study_goal: To examine the effects of long-term progressive resistance exercise (PRE) and modified Fitness Counts (mFC) on physical function outcomes in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: Both PRE and mFC improved physical function measures over 24 months when tested on medication, except for the 6-minute walk test (6MWT). Off medication, all measures, including 6MWT, showed significant improvement.
population_specificity: 38 patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) alone versus PTA with bare metal stenting for treating superficial femoral artery stenoses in improving vessel patency, quality of life, ankle brachial index, and treadmill walking distance.
results_summary: The study found a short-term improvement in primary duplex patency at six and 12 months with PTA plus stenting compared to PTA alone, but this benefit was not sustained at 24 months. No significant improvements were observed in ankle brachial index, treadmill walking distance, or quality of life between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Participants with symptomatic lower limb peripheral vascular disease (Rutherford categories 1 to 6; Fontaine stages II to IV), average age 69 years, including men and women.
study_duration: Follow-up for up to two years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of biventricular pacing (BVP) and isolated left ventricular pacing (LVP) in treating chronic heart failure, focusing on how QRS duration influences outcomes.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found BVP and LVP were comparable in most efficacy parameters, but BVP showed significantly greater improvement in 6-min walking distance as QRS duration increased.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether positively-framed messages could more effectively encourage walking in older adults compared to negatively-framed or neutral messages.
results_summary: Positively-framed messages significantly increased walking in older adults, while negatively-framed messages were less effective. The effect of positive messaging was sustained over a 28-day period.
population_specificity: Older adults (compared to younger adults in Study 1).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention focused on messaging, not walking dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of ankle-foot deformity in gait impairment among chronic hemiplegic patients with equinus deformity.
results_summary: The study identified five subgroups of patients with distinct gait dysfunction levels, linking faster walking to less ankle-foot impairment or stiffness, while slower walking was associated with instability, severe equinus, and hip rotation patterns. Clustering gait patterns helped understand dysfunction and guide targeted treatment.
population_specificity: 49 chronic hemiplegic patients with equinus deformity of the foot.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify specific gait deficits in patients after total hip arthroplasty compared to healthy controls and between operated and non-operated limbs during daily activities.
results_summary: The study found reductions in sagittal range of motion, peak extension, power generation, and moments in the operated hip compared to controls, with persistent deficits in walking speed and step length at long-term follow-up. Hip abduction moment deficits were consistent across level walking and stair ascent.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty for primary osteoarthritis, compared to healthy controls.
study_duration: Follow-up periods of at least six months after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the intra-session repeatability of local dynamic stability (LDS) in neurological patients and assess its discriminative power to differentiate between healthy individuals and neurological patients.
results_summary: LDS showed high intra-session repeatability (ICC = 0.89) and effectively differentiated neurological patients from healthy controls (33% relative difference, standardized effect size 2.3), suggesting its potential for fall risk prediction.
population_specificity: 83 patients with mild to moderate neurological disorders and 40 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of chronic kidney disease (CKD) on functional capacity, including walking performance (6MWT), and its correlation with quality of life, respiratory function, and other factors in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that children with CKD walked a mean distance of 396 meters in the 6MWT, with positive correlations between walking distance and age, height, quality of life, and lung function. Transplanted patients and physically active children had better quality of life scores compared to those on hemodialysis or sedentary lifestyles.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (aged 8-17 years) with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of sildenafil on blood pressure, skeletal muscle oxygenation, and walking tolerance in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Sildenafil lowered blood pressure and improved skeletal muscle oxygenation during exercise but did not enhance walking tolerance in patients with intermittent claudication. Pain-free and maximal walking times did not differ significantly between sildenafil and placebo trials.
population_specificity: 12 men with stable intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: Two consecutive doses of 50 mg sildenafil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral nitric oxide (NO) supplementation on blood pressure, functional capacity (including walking distance), and quality of life in patients with clinical prehypertension.
results_summary: NO supplementation significantly reduced resting blood pressure and increased walking distance in the 6-minute walk test, along with improvements in quality of life scores.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with clinical prehypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aerobic physical exercise (walking with strides) on menopausal symptoms, blood lipid status, and body weight in middle-aged female medical staff with perimenopausal syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that walking significantly reduced menopausal symptoms (measured by the Kupperman index), improved blood lipid profiles (lowered total cholesterol and triglycerides), and decreased body weight and waist circumference compared to the control group. These changes were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Middle-aged female medical staff (aged 40-55) with perimenopausal syndrome (Kupperman index score ≥15).
effective_dosage: Walking with strides three times a week or more.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treadmill training provided greater benefits to community-dwelling stroke survivors who walked faster than 0.4m/s compared to those who walked more slowly.
results_summary: Treadmill training improved walking distance (72m extra) and comfortable speed (0.16m/s increase) in participants with baseline speeds >0.4m/s, but no long-term differences were observed between subgroups. No extra effect was seen in health status (EuroQol 5Q-5D).
population_specificity: 68 community-dwelling stroke survivors.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of treadmill and overground walking, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze genetic mutations in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and correlate them with clinical and functional parameters, including the 6-minute walking test.
results_summary: The study found that pathogenic mutations in BMPR2, ACVRL1, and KCNA5 genes were associated with more severe clinical and hemodynamic parameters, including worse performance in the 6-minute walking test.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic and associated PAH (41 patients and 50 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical applicability of GPS-monitored community-based walking ability assessment in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: GPS recordings were technically satisfactory in 85% of patients on the first attempt and 93% after a second attempt. The study found that GPS-measured walking distances were significantly higher than self-reported distances, and walking speed was consistent with few variations.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) who complained of intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate effects of Balance-based torso-weighting (BBTW) on gait parameters in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and healthy controls.
results_summary: With BBTW, PwMS showed significant improvements in gait velocity, cadence, and time spent in single-limb support, while healthy controls exhibited increased velocity and cadence at fast speeds. The findings suggest BBTW may enhance gait stability in PwMS.
population_specificity: 20 people with multiple sclerosis and 20 matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine differences in symmetry in external work between four categories of prosthetic feet in K-Level-2 and K-Level-3 unilateral transtibial amputees during ramp ascent and descent.
results_summary: K-Level-2 subjects showed higher symmetry in external work with Talux and Proprio-Foot during ramp descent compared to solid ankle cushion heel feet. K-Level-3 subjects also had better symmetry with Talux. No significant differences were found during ramp ascent.
population_specificity: Unilateral transtibial amputees classified as K-Level-2 or K-Level-3.
study_duration: 10- to 14-day accommodation period per prosthetic foot

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of supervision on walking capacity in patients with intermittent claudication, testing the hypothesis that higher supervision intensity improves walking distance.
results_summary: Supervised exercise therapy (SET) was superior to other conservative treatments in improving walking distances at all follow-ups, with a direct relationship between supervision intensity and walking capacity. However, the difference between home-based exercise (HB-ET) and SET at 6 months was not significant.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (1406 participants across 30 studies).
study_duration: Follow-ups at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online-delivered physical activity intervention for increasing walking in cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study protocol describes an innovative tool using ratings of perceived exertion and daily affect to create individualized step goals, potentially improving physical and psychological outcomes in cancer survivors. Results are pending as the abstract describes the study design rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors aged 18 or older, living in metropolitan and rural areas of South Australia, who were insufficiently active.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step goals individualized based on daily reporting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationships between hip and knee osteoarthritis (OA) and physical performance (PP), particularly walking speed, chair rises, and balance, in older adults across six European countries.
results_summary: The study found that clinical knee OA, hip OA, or both were significantly associated with lower physical performance, with the highest risk observed in individuals with OA at both sites. These relationships remained robust even after adjusting for confounders like pain, age, gender, and body mass index.
population_specificity: 2,942 men and women aged 65-85 years from Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, and the UK.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the efficacy of various treatments, including statins, for improving walking capacity in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that statins may improve walking capacity in PAD patients, but no specific results or data on walking are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine mediators of an exercise intervention (including walking) on sleep quality in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in sleep duration but no significant mediators for sleep duration or latency. Daytime somnolence was mediated by inflammation markers and fatigue.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal breast cancer survivors (Stage II or lower, off primary treatment).
effective_dosage: 160 minutes/week of moderate-intensity aerobic walking, plus twice-weekly resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and potential effects of a walking exercise program on fatigue, physical function, and well-being in people with advanced cancer.
results_summary: The study found that the walking intervention (STEPS) significantly reduced fatigue (OR 3.68) and showed modest improvements in well-being (OR 2.36), though physical function improvements were less pronounced (OR 1.40). The trial suggests a personalized exercise program may be beneficial but requires a larger study for confirmation.
population_specificity: People with advanced cancer undergoing interdisciplinary assessment and rehabilitation, with fatigue levels of 4-10 on a visual analogue scale.
effective_dosage: 8-week fatigue-adapted walking intervention facilitated using a pedometer (specific step count not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the incidence, consequences, and risk factors for harm in people with dementia who got lost in a UK policing region.
results_summary: The study found that getting lost was a low-frequency event (0.5% incidence) but posed significant risks for a small minority (5% sustained harm, including two deaths). Harm was associated with older age, longer time missing, and seasonal factors.
population_specificity: People with dementia in one UK policing region (population 2.1 million).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise, including walking, improves health outcomes in adults with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and identify optimal exercise strategies for this population.
results_summary: The study found that regular exercise training, including walking, improved aerobic capacity, muscular functioning, cardiovascular function, walking capacity, and health-related quality of life in individuals with CKD, though most data focused on dialysis patients using aerobic exercise programs.
population_specificity: Adults with CKD stages 2-5, dialysis therapy, or a kidney transplant.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise training for at least 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare performance error and perceived difficulty during toe-out gait modification in people with knee osteoarthritis using three types of visual feedback.
results_summary: Real-time biofeedback resulted in significantly less toe-out performance error compared to mirror and raw video feedback, though the difference was small (2°). Perceived difficulty did not differ significantly between the feedback methods.
population_specificity: 20 individuals with knee osteoarthritis (11 women, mean age 65.4±9.8 years; 7 mild, 9 moderate, 4 severe cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 1-year patency and effectiveness of the Pulsar-18 self-expanding nitinol stent for treating femoropopliteal occlusive disease in a real-world, multicenter registry.
results_summary: The study found promising primary patency rates (79.5% at 12 months) and freedom from target lesion revascularization (81% at 12 months), with significant improvements in ankle-brachial index, pain-free walking distance, and Rutherford category. Diabetes and renal insufficiency did not negatively impact patency.
population_specificity: 118 patients (64 men; mean age 71.9±9.6 years) with symptomatic femoropopliteal lesions (Rutherford category 2-5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and preliminary effects of high-intensity task-oriented circuit training (TOCT) on walking competency, mobility, fatigue, and health-related quality of life in multiple sclerosis (MS) subjects.
results_summary: After TOCT, subjects reported improved walking ability and health-related quality of life, with minor retention after 3 months. The control group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 24 MS subjects with moderate mobility impairments (EDSS 4.89 ± 0.54, 17 female, 7 male, mean age 52.58 ± 11.21 years, MS duration 15.21 ± 8.68 years).
effective_dosage: 10 TOCT sessions over 2 weeks (2 hours each session) followed by a 3-month home exercise program.
study_duration: 2 weeks of TOCT plus 3 months of home-based exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess factors influencing physical activity levels, including walking, during break-times in South African primary school children.
results_summary: The study found that 29% of learners were observed walking during break-times, with no significant differences between intervention and control groups. Walking levels were not specifically analyzed for efficacy or outcomes beyond general activity categorization.
population_specificity: South African primary school children from low-income schools.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether strengthening the triceps surae and quadriceps femoris muscle-tendon units through exercise could influence mechanical and biological markers of knee osteoarthritis in elderly individuals during incline walking.
results_summary: Post-intervention, participants showed improved muscle strength and tendon stiffness, reduced knee and hip adduction moments during walking, and enhanced ankle pushoff function, but no significant change in serum COMP levels. The study highlighted the role of ankle pushoff in knee joint loading but did not demonstrate a clear biological benefit for knee cartilage.
population_specificity: Twelve older women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interval walking improves postprandial glucose tolerance and free-living glycemia more effectively than continuous walking in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Interval walking (IW) significantly reduced mean and maximal incremental plasma glucose levels compared to both continuous walking (CW) and control (CON), and improved metabolic clearance rate. IW also lowered mean glucose levels for the rest of the intervention day compared to CW, though no differences were observed the following day.
population_specificity: 10 individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: Three 1-hour interventions (interval walking, continuous walking, and control).
study_duration: 1-hour sessions with follow-up measurements over approximately 32 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of football (soccer) and strength training on performance and functional ability in older, untrained men, including their physiological responses to submaximal exercise like walking.
results_summary: Both football and strength training improved functional ability and reduced heart rate during walking, with football also enhancing maximal aerobic fitness and exhaustive exercise performance. Football showed greater improvements in VO₂ max and endurance compared to strength training.
population_specificity: 26 untrained older men (average age 68.2 ± 3.2 years).
effective_dosage: Football training: 1.6 ± 0.1 times per week; Strength training: 1.5 ± 0.1 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a robotic knee brace could improve walking ability in stroke survivors compared to a group exercise program.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait velocity (primary outcome) between the robotic therapy and group exercise groups, with inconsistent improvements in secondary measures for both groups. No complications were reported with robotic therapy.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with chronic hemiparesis after stroke (24 participants, 20 completed the study).
effective_dosage: 18 hours of therapy (either robotic or group exercise) over 6 weeks.
study_duration: 6-week training period with follow-up at 3 months (week 19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which treatment options for idiopathic toe-walking (ITW) gait have the best long-term effect based on existing evidence.
results_summary: The study found no single treatment option with a long-term effect on ITW gait, though surgical interventions, serial casting, and botulinum toxin type A had some support. Limited evidence suggested footwear or orthoses did not change the gait pattern.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic toe-walking (ITW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a walking intervention during pregnancy on post-partum weight retention in obese/overweight women and infant growth outcomes.
results_summary: The walking intervention significantly reduced post-partum weight retention in obese women compared to controls, with a lower percentage retaining >5 kg at 6 months. Offspring of obese women in the control group showed a consistently higher growth trend than those in the intervention group, though statistically non-significant.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese, previously non-exercising pregnant women.
study_duration: From pregnancy (exact trimester not specified) to 6 months post-partum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether marching in place or rater observation during walking provided more consistent foot placement for standing posture measurements.
results_summary: The study found that marching in place resulted in more consistent foot placement between sessions compared to rater observation during walking, with high reliability among participants and raters.
population_specificity: 20 individuals (12 women, 8 men; mean age 24.8 years).
study_duration: Short-term (10 seconds of marching in place, followed by walking over an 8-m walkway).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional capacity, pulmonary shunt fraction, and clinical outcomes between patients with pleural drains placed in sub-xyphoid versus intercostal positions after off-pump coronary artery bypass surgery.
results_summary: The sub-xyphoid pleural drain group showed better preservation of lung function, smaller pulmonary shunt fraction, improved functional capacity, lower pain scores, and better clinical outcomes compared to the intercostal group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing off-pump coronary artery bypass surgery.
study_duration: Assessed preoperatively and on postoperative days 1 and 5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate informed decision-making regarding amputation for CRPS-I, including reasons for amputation, levels chosen, and postoperative outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that amputation decisions were collaborative, weighing factors like pain, infection, and psychological flags. Postoperative complications included infection (22%) and high rates of phantom pain (72% initially, 77% long-term).
population_specificity: Thirty-six patients with CRPS-I who underwent amputation at a university medical center from 2000 to 2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quadriceps-sparing (QS) technique with medial parapatellar arthrotomy (MPPA) for total knee arthroplasty to determine which led to better patient-reported function, less postoperative pain, and reduced opioid utilization.
results_summary: The QS group reported significantly less pain at rest on postoperative day one and with activity on day three, but no differences were found in opioid utilization or early functional advantages between the two techniques. Both groups showed significant improvements in knee function and walking independence over time.
population_specificity: 129 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
study_duration: Follow-up at one and three months post-surgery, with weekly telephone interviews for eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare energy costs during walking and movement initiation times in children with developmental delay (DD) and children with typical development (TD).
results_summary: The study found that children with DD had similar physiological costs of walking as children with TD but walked at a lower speed and took more time to initiate goal-directed walking.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 to 5 years with developmental delay (DD) or typical development (TD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define and assess the reliability of six perceptual signs in children with cerebral palsy and explore their potential link to motor prognosis, such as time to independent walking.
results_summary: The study found moderate interobserver reliability for four perceptual signs and fair reliability for two others, with high agreement between independent observers and the gold standard. The signs may help identify a new class of patients and aid in functional prognosis assessment.
population_specificity: 19 children with bilateral cerebral palsy and 35 rehabilitation professionals (9 doctors, 26 physiotherapists) from Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (LVR) coil treatment in patients with homogeneous emphysema, focusing on improvements in exercise capacity (6-minute walking distance) and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that LVR coil treatment significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, forced vital capacity, residual volume, and quality of life scores at 6 months, with an acceptable safety profile. Adverse events included two COPD exacerbations and one small pneumothorax.
population_specificity: Patients with severe homogeneous emphysema and airway obstruction.
effective_dosage: A median of 11 (range 10-12) coils per lung, administered in two sequential procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether virtual reality (VR) with varying audio and optic flow cues could safely increase walking speed in individuals with and without musculoskeletal pain (MSP).
results_summary: Audio tempo above baseline cadence significantly increased walking speed in both groups by over 25% without increasing pain, while optic flow showed a non-significant trend toward increased speed.
population_specificity: 36 subjects (19 with MSP, 17 controls).
effective_dosage: Audio tempo scaled to 75%, 100%, and 125% of baseline cadence; optic flow scaled to 50% or 100% of preferred walking speed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and safety of endothelin blockade with bosentan in adult patients with Fontan physiology, focusing on its effects on cardiac output and functional capacity, including walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that bosentan improved 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) by 73 meters and increased MRI-derived resting cardiac output, suggesting positive effects on pulmonary vascular resistance and blood flow. Adverse events were minor and manageable, with no significant impact on hepatic function.
population_specificity: Adult patients with Fontan physiology (n=10, with 7 completing the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and effectiveness of a comprehensive postoperative rehabilitation program versus usual care for improving strength, walking endurance, and functional outcomes in younger patients (<65 years) after total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between groups, but the intervention group showed clinically important improvements in strength. Walking endurance and self-reported outcomes (WOMAC and RAND-36) improved significantly in both groups, with no clinically important differences between them. Ceiling effects were noted for WOMAC pain and function scores.
population_specificity: Patients under 65 years who underwent primary total hip arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and initial efficacy of electroacupuncture for improving peripheral neuropathy symptoms, including walking, in multiple myeloma patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking test performance (21.6 vs. 17.2, p=0.0003) and other neuropathy-related outcomes, with moderate to large effect sizes observed from week 4 onward. No significant changes were noted in nerve conduction studies (NCS).
population_specificity: Cancer patients with multiple myeloma experiencing thalidomide/bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy (grade ≥2).
effective_dosage: 20 acupuncture treatments over 9 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 PUFA supplementation reduces cardiovascular events and complications in adults with peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of a protective association of omega-3 PUFA supplementation against major adverse cardiac events or other serious clinical outcomes. Adverse events and compliance were poorly reported.
population_specificity: Adults with peripheral arterial disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether targeted physical therapy combined with cranial nerve non-invasive neuromodulation (CN-NINM) improves walking ability in people with MS exhibiting dysfunctional gait.
results_summary: Both groups showed improved Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) scores, but the active CN-NINM group demonstrated statistically greater improvement compared to the control group. The study suggests tongue-based neurostimulation may enhance exercise benefits for gait improvement in chronic MS patients.
population_specificity: Twenty chronic multiple sclerosis (MS) patients with identified gait disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) of the premotor cortex could provide clinical benefits for spastic hemiparetic patients, particularly in improving walking and reducing reflex excitability.
results_summary: Low-frequency TMS (1 Hz) showed significant reductions in reflex excitability and ankle stiffness, with modest improvements in walking cadence and recurvatum, but no significant changes in clinical spasticity signs. No effects were observed with placebo or 10 Hz stimulation.
population_specificity: Five spastic hemiparetic patients
study_duration: Effects were measured 9 and 31 days after initiation of TMS

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the characteristics of functional exercise performance and determinants of the cycle endurance test (CET) and six-minute walk test (6MWT) in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that COPD patients had impaired exercise tolerance, with gender differences in performance (men had longer CET-Tend and higher 6MWD). Gender, BMI, FEV1, and FRC were key determinants of exercise performance in CET and 6MWT.
population_specificity: 2053 COPD patients (43% female, age 66.9 ± 9.5 years, FEV1% predicted 48.2 ± 23.2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an ankle-foot orthosis improves mediolateral foot-placement ability during walking in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: The study found that while the ankle-foot orthosis corrected foot and ankle alignment, it did not significantly improve hip hiking, circumduction, coronal plane hip range of motion, or mediolateral foot-placement ability. The orthosis may affect other balance aspects not tested in the study.
population_specificity: Post-stroke individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether using the nociceptive withdrawal reflex to support gait training improves walking outcomes in subacute post-stroke patients compared to standard physiotherapy alone.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant improvements in preferred and fast walking velocities, stance phase duration, gait cycle duration, and stance time symmetry ratio compared to the control group, particularly in severely impaired patients. No differences were found in the Functional Ambulation Category test between groups post-treatment.
population_specificity: Subacute post-stroke patients with gait deficits, particularly those with severe walking impairment.
effective_dosage: Electrical stimuli delivered to the arch of the foot at heel-off to elicit the withdrawal reflex (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated; assessments were conducted before, immediately after, one month, and six months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of whole-body resistance training on exercise capacity, health-related quality of life, and muscle strength in patients hospitalized for exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
results_summary: The training group improved lower-limb muscle strength and 6-minute walking distance during and after hospitalization, along with better health-related quality of life and reduced inflammatory markers, while the control group showed reduced muscle strength without changes in walking distance. No improvement in daily physical activity levels was observed in the training group.
population_specificity: Patients hospitalized for exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (N=46 randomized, 29 completed).
effective_dosage: 2 sets of 8 repetitions per muscle group, initial load set at 80% of 1-repetition maximum.
study_duration: Evaluated during hospitalization, at discharge, and 30 days post-discharge (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the concurrent validity of the Microsoft Kinect™ as a low-cost motion analysis tool compared to the Vicon Nexus system for measuring sagittal plane gait kinematics during walking and jogging.
results_summary: The Kinect™ generally underestimated joint flexion and overestimated extension, with low correlation and large error for hip measurements, while knee measurements were somewhat better but inconsistent for clinical use. Stride timing measurements showed high correlation and small error, with variability smallest at the slowest velocity.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy adults (nine male, 11 female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether video game-based balance training (Wii Fit) was more effective than usual balance therapy in improving functional balance and reducing disability in subacute stroke patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: Wii Fit training significantly improved balance (Berg Balance Scale) and independence in daily living (Barthel Index) compared to usual balance therapy, with statistically significant results (P = 0.004 and P = 0.021, respectively). No significant differences were reported for walking ability or speed.
population_specificity: Fifty adult subacute stroke patients with hemiparesis.
effective_dosage: Conventional physical therapy (40 minutes, 2 times/day) plus Wii Fit or usual balance therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of prolonged sitting versus sitting interrupted by brief bouts of light or moderate-intensity walking on resting blood pressure in overweight/obese adults.
results_summary: Interrupting prolonged sitting with light or moderate-intensity walking significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to uninterrupted sitting, with no significant changes in mean arterial pressure or heart rate.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults aged 45-65 years (n = 19).
effective_dosage: 2 min bouts of light-intensity walking (3.2 km/h) or moderate-intensity walking (5.8-6.4 km/h) every 20 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of various exercise training modalities, including walking, for patients with chronic respiratory disease as part of pulmonary rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that ground walking, Nordic walking, and other exercise modalities are feasible and effective for subgroups of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and can be integrated into comprehensive pulmonary rehabilitation programs.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic respiratory disease, specifically chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of two patellar exposure techniques (lateral retraction vs. eversion) during total knee arthroplasty, focusing on quadriceps strength and other functional measures.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in quadriceps strength, range of motion, or quality-of-life scores between the two techniques at one year postoperatively, suggesting comparable outcomes for both methods.
population_specificity: 120 patients with degenerative arthrosis undergoing primary total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical techniques compared, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of specifically adapted exercise programs, both alone and combined with a back school program, on pain, disability, muscle strength, walking performance, and other outcomes in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Both exercise-only and exercise-plus-back-school groups showed statistically significant improvements in pain, disability, muscle strength, walking performance (6MWT), and quality of life, with greater improvements in the combined intervention group. These benefits persisted at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 121 patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
effective_dosage: Exercise treatment performed 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of home-based pulmonary rehabilitation, including walking, for improving quality of life, breathlessness, and exercise capacity in patients with severe and very severe COPD.
results_summary: The study found that home-based pulmonary rehabilitation, which included walking, significantly improved quality of life, reduced breathlessness in daily activities, and increased exercise capacity in patients with severe COPD, though no significant changes were observed in pulmonary function.
population_specificity: Patients with severe and very severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Training included endurance exercises like walking, stair climbing, cycling, and treadmill walking, with frequency adjusted based on patient resources (initially 2 weekly physiotherapist visits, then twice monthly, plus weekly calls).
